newsitem.title: MEXICO: Pemex E&P to spend to 46.75 mln pesos in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Pemex E&P to spend to 46.75 mln pesos in 1997.

text.p: Mexico's state-owned oil and gas monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex) plans to spend 46.75 million pesos on exploration and production in 1997, the director general of the company's E&P unit said in an industry conference on Friday.

Of the E&P unit's budget, about 80 percent will be spent on investment aimed "principally toward the expansion of hydrocarbon production," Pemex's exploration and production director general Jose Antonio Ceballos Soberanis said in a statement.
"The strategy considers the reactivation of exploited fields, crude production, an increase in the extraction of gas and condensates," he added.

Among the projects Pemex has highlighted are plans to invest 1.198 billion pesos to expand the Burgus Basin natural gas production. The company expects to spend 3.886 billion pesos on boosting offshore crude extraction and 8.143 billion pesos on extending output at its largest producing oil field, Cantarell.

The projects will require certain private investments that will be auctioned as need arises, Ceballos said. Pemex has exclusive control over hydrocarbon extraction but contracts private companies for well construction and equipment.
Companies commonly contracted by Pemex are seen benefitting from the company's expected increased output for 1997.
Pemex aims to produce 3.08 million barrels per day (bpd) of crude oil and 4.545 billion cubic feet per day (cfd) of natural gas.
Of 1997 investment, the company plans to spend 26.626 billion pesos on drilling and capital construction projects.
Principal construction projects will be the building and installing of land and marine ducts, offshore structures, compression, production and drilling platforms and storage tanks, Ceballos said.
